entry.title: Re: How to apply a filter on a single property of a data...
entry.content:
Hi @Dan_Wroblewski

Thanks for your answer. Yes, that's exactly what we want: we need to return all items of the data set whose account.id field is in the accountTechnicalId variable.

 
The reason why we're using a GetRecordCollection is because we need to display the filtered list in our app via a list item component (logic flow behind this being GetRecordCollection>SetAppVariable) and the accountTechnicalIds are retrieved using the logged on user's email. Plus, the API (sap.crm.caseservice.api.case in our case) is linked to Sales Cloud and has already been set up using a Universal Rest API integration.
 
Note that we're going back over a project that was initially outsourced. So ideally we'd like to use what has already been implemented. That's why we wonder if there's a way to do this by just modifying the formula written in the editor...
 
Thanks.
 
LM.

entry.title: Re: Update asset useful life
entry.content:
When you change the useful life the depreciation is recalculated, this results in new postings. The posting period is however closed.

I expect that 2024 is still open in asset accounting. If you close the Asset Accounting fiscal year for 2024 only recalculations will be made for 2025. (it's best to close the AA year together with the general FI posting periods on year end).

entry.title: Error R1149: Application object BUPA: Table SZA1_D0100 does not exist during BP creation
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am encountering a blocking error while trying to create/edit a Business Partner (BP) in our S/4HANA system.

Steps to Reproduce:

  1. Open Transaction BP 

  2. Select 'Create Organization' (or Person/Group).

  3. After entering basic data and attempting to save or move to a different tab, the following error pops up:

    Application object BUPA: Table SZA1_D0100 does not exist (Message No. R1149).

Environment Details:

  • System: SAP S/4HANA

  • Transaction: BP / Desktop Version

Investigation Done So Far:

  • I checked table SZA1_D0100 in SE11, and the table exists in the Data Dictionary.

  • I suspect it might be related to a mandatory field configuration or a link issue in the Business Data Toolset (BDT).

Could someone please guide me on how to resolve this? Is there a specific entry I need to check in transaction BUSB or BUSG?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: How to Test OAuth-Enabled Inbound Communication in SAP Using an API Client
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog post explains how to test OAuth-enabled inbound communication in SAP using an API client. It walks through the configuration steps and provides practical examples for validating the setup.

When working with inbound communication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud or on-premises systems, developers and integration specialists often need a lightweight tool to test APIs secured with OAuth 2.0.

While there are many API testing tools available today, this guide focuses on Bruno‚Äîa modern, open-source similar to the more established Postman. Personally I think of Postman as the old guard, and Bruno as the new pup on the block: sleek, efficient, and eager to fetch your tokens! (And yes, my love for dogs may have influenced this choice just a little.) 
                                                                         

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 üêæ In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to:

  1. Configure a custom communication arrangement based on an existing communication scenario for OAuth 2.0
  2. Use an API client to test inbound communication secured with OAuth 2.0

Note: This guide assumes you already have a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0.

Prerequisites

  • A communication scenario in your S/4HANA system that supports OAuth 2.0
  • An API client installed on your operating system (for example, Bruno, Postman, or any equivalent tool)

So, grab your treats and let‚Äôs get our paws dirty‚ÄîBruno‚Äôs ready to sniff out those OAuth tokens and help you unleash smoother integrations!

Step 1: Enable a Custom Communication Arrangement for OAuth

1. Create a Communication System and Communication User

üêæ Think of the Communication System as Bruno‚Äôs doghouse‚Äîit needs to be cozy, secure, and ready for visitors. üêæ

Open the Communication Systems app and create a new system:

System IDZ_BRUNO
System NameZ_BRUNO


Under Technical Data:

  1. Enable Inbound Only.
  2. In OAuth 2.0 Settings: 
    • Set Client Redirect URI Type to Loopback
    • Set a path in the Path field, e.g., /bruno/redirect
          ‚Üí This becomes your Callback URL:   http://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect (used in Step 2)

üêæ When you set the redirect path to /bruno/redirect, you‚Äôre basically telling Bruno where to wag his tail when he‚Äôs done fetching the token. üêæ

Under Users for Inbound Communication

  1.  Add a new communication user
  2.  Set Authentication Method to OAuth 2.0
  3.  Define OAuth 2.0 Client ID, e.g., Z_BRUNO_ID
  4. Enable Refresh Allowed and set Refresh Token Expiry Time, e.g., 5 Days

Save your communication system and inbound communication user for your future testing with Bruno acting as OAuth client. This user will be later used for the Authorization Code Grant with PKCE.

2. Create a Communication Arrangement

Open the Communication Arrangements app and create a new arrangement based on a communication scenario that supports OAuth 2.0 as an authentication method, e.g., SAP_COM_0053 (Purchase Order Integration).

ScenarioSAP_COM_0053 (exists only in S/4HANA Cloud)
Arrangement NameTEST_COM_0053_WITH_BRUNO
Communication System Z_BRUNO (defined earlier)

Under Inbound Communication:

 

  1. Enter the OAuth 2.0 Client ID you defined earlier: Z_BRUNO_ID.
  2. Save your communication arrangement.

Note: Only after saving the arrangement, the previously defined OAuth client gets actually created. A clickable label OAuth 2.0 Details will apear.

In OAuth 2.0 Details, you will find all the necessary data for your API client:

  1. Client ID
  2. Token Service URL
  3.  Authorization URL

These are needed to fetch a token with Bruno.

Now you are ready to test your OAuth-secured API using Bruno!


Step 2: Use Bruno to Test the OAuth Communication

Image was created by the author using an AI illustration tool and is original content.

 

 

1. Create a New Collection

üêæ  Creating a new collection in Bruno is like giving your dog a new toy‚Äîname it, set it up, and let the fun begin!  üêæ

  1. Open Bruno
  2. Create a New Collection
  3. Name it, e.g., My_test_collection

2. Set Up OAuth in the Auth Tab

  1. Go to the Auth tab and choose OAuth 2.0
  2. Set up the configurations:

     

Grant TypeAuthorization Code
Callback URLhttp://127.0.0.1/bruno/redirect
Authorization URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Access Token URLFrom Communication Arrangement
Client IDFrom Communication Arrangement
Statedummy
Use PKCE check box‚úÖenabled

üêæ  Don‚Äôt forget to enable PKCE‚Äîit‚Äôs like putting a leash on your OAuth flow. Keeps things secure and under control. üêæ

3. Send a Test Request

  1. Choose Get Access Token
  2. A browser window will open -  logon as a Business User
  3. Approve the request by clicking Allow

  4. If successful, you‚Äôll receive an Access Token. 
    The response typically appears in the Response tab in JSON format like this:

     

  5. Use this token to call your API services:


Troubleshooting Tips

  • Make sure you log in with a Business User assigned to the correct Business Roles for the API.
  • If you see the following screen after logging in:

it likely means the user lacks the required authorizations or the wrong user was used.

Summary

With this setup, you can securely test OAuth-protected endpoints in SAP using Bruno or similar tools. This approach is useful for validating integration scenarios and troubleshooting authentication issues.

Bruno provides a clean and open-source alternative to Postman for testing OAuth-secured APIs in SAP S/4HANA. With just a few configuration steps, you can simulate real-world OAuth flows and validate your communication scenarios with ease.

üêæ With Bruno by your side, testing OAuth APIs is less of a chore and more of a walk in the park. Just don‚Äôt forget the treats (a.k.a. access tokens)! üêæ

 

Image Attribution and Licensing

All illustrations in this post were created by the author using Microsoft Copilot (AI-based design tool) for educational purposes. The images are original content and free to use under the author‚Äôs permission for non-commercial, educational purposes. No external branding or promotional elements are included.

entry.title: Why using the dynamic variant of CALL TRANSFORMATION if the static one can be used?
entry.content:
I see that my fellow developers like using this dynamic variant of CALL TRANFORMATION ("SOURCE (variable)", with VARIABLE being of type ABAP_TRANS_RESBIND_TAB):

    DATA : lt_xml_dyn TYPE abap_trans_resbind_tab,
           ls_xml_dyn TYPE abap_trans_resbind.

    GET REFERENCE OF gt_ot INTO ls_xml_dyn-value.
    ls_xml_dyn-name = 'DATA'.
    INSERT ls_xml_dyn INTO TABLE lt_xml_dyn.

    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE (lt_xml_dyn)
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

They can't explain why they are doing this way; in fact, they have copied an existing snippet and don't know there's a simpler way.

I recommend using the short static form instead:

    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE data = gt_ot
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

Do you see any advantage of using the dynamic variant if the static variant can be used? 

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: How to export Customer credit segment data?
entry.content:
Good day MSSAP07

Thank you for your question

Yes, you are right that Export Master Data-Business Partners does not cover credit segment level fields. For you to extract validations in public cloud, I would recommend using Embedded Analytics through released CDS view. See possible CDS view you can use for credit segment level data: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/fc3f5ae432cb4338aa538e403b98c9e5.html

Here is a quick guidance you can consider in your system.

Open View Browser app and search for I_CreditManagementAccount, confirm it contains fields that you need such as Credit Segment and Credit Limit


Open Custom Analytical Query app. Create a new query with Credit Account Extended as your data source.

Add the fields Business Partner, Credit Segment, Credit Limit & Currency, you may also add any other available segment attributes you need. Run the query and use Export to Spreadsheet.

Go to Filters tab and add Credit Segment, so you can run the extract per segment


For Risk Class, Calculation Rule, Credit Check Rule, these are usually on the credit master side. If they are not in the same CDS views then you create a CDS View (join) based on receivables management CDS views and then build the analytical query on top. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/ef6799c84da64eb3aa51ba8b4eed8d3c.html for more details.

 

Another option is to extract through standard A2X API if you want full field coverage and automation. Credit Management Master Data that supports inbound service to help you read credit management data, including segment data is available and can you can find more details here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ce8c2b9687e94c2eb70ab34e92e6fba5/64e8c928499341ffb0eaac517a882b7d.html

Here are APIs to support that: https://api.sap.com/api/API_CRDTMBUSINESSPARTNER/resource/Credit_Account_Collateral

You will have to use the SAP_COM_0740 communication scenario which only available if you have activated scope item 1QM. See KBA 3436543 for more details.

 

Open the Communications Arrangement app, create an arrangement for SAP_COM_0740

Call the API and export your results to CSV for validation. Make use of the Credit Management Account entity for segment level and use Credit Management Business Partner entity for profile fields.

 

To summarise, In your case I would:

  • If you need a one time validation extract, I will choose the Custom Analytical Query and export option.
  • If you need a repeatable monthly control report or full coverage of credit profile fields then I would create the communication.

 

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Income tax/Direct tax and Tax ledger
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog post takes a sides step from Controlling related topics, and focuses on direct tax, however, we still circle around highlighting new functionalities and comparing functionalities between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (at the time of writing the latest SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition release is 2025, while the earlier mentioned is 2508). 

Typically, in S/4HANA projects you focus on Transactional taxes, like, VAT, e-invoicing mandates, and other tax related topics, which are more ‚Äúurgent‚Äù from operative reporting and compliance point of view. However, direct tax should not be overlooked as there are fundamental building blocks, which can help in automating the process, some which are more costly to implement at a later stage ( in Private Cloud Edition), while others doesn‚Äôt matter that when they are implemented (e.g. taking  SAP Profitability and performance management into use).

 

Figure 1: Overview of SAP Tax solutions.

 

You might still wonder, why bother with this, we have managed well earlier also, there are not that big difference between local GAAP and income tax?

  • Well, you have items which are handled differently, e.g. pensions, can be deductible in tax, but not in local GAAP, you can have different depreciation rules for tax, you might have certain fixed and temporary difference between local gap and tax. Furthermore, bad debt and e different handling between local GAAP and direct tax. All that leads to the fact that income tax calculation requires different set of information and different rules to calculate your financials.
  • There are also companies that face a need to automate this process, or want further transparency and auditability, which are also drivers for improving direct tax process.

1.     Direct Tax in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition

To support direct tax calculation in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition you can decide whether you want to have a (ie. a standard, non-leading ledger), have an extension ledger for tax or only to have tax depreciation areas for reporting purposes (without a real tax ledger).

  • A) Standard ledger. The s Meaning direct integration from Asset accounting into this ledger. A standard ledger allows also integration from other sub-ledgers, like Revenue Accounting and Lease Accounting or Treasury. This ledger will also include all postings that are done meaning all standard postings (invoices, material movements, normal closing postings, etc.). Additionally, this ledger would include all the other postings that are only valid for direct tax, which enables for direct tax audits you have also all postings in one place). Database size should also be considered with this approach, as it will increase.
    • This approach requires also efforts, as you need to do closing activities for this ledger, so more efforts are required to maintain it. Adding a full ledger and asset accounting after go-live is possible, however, there are limitations and requires usually more work (further details: Subsequent Implementation of a Further Accounting Principle SAP HELP & 2403248 - FI-AA (new): Availability of RAFABNEW & 430618 - Procedure for setting up new depreciation area), in this scenario you should also review all the subledgers required for the new accounting principle and not only Asset Accounting. Subsequent addition of an accounting principle is not yet possible if Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA) is activated.
  • B) Extension ledger. (reported together with the underlying ledger). An extension ledger supports only manual postings to balance sheet and P&L accounts. No postings to reconciliation accounts or other automated postings are supported. This means that no manual postings to subledgers, vendor, customer, asset or material can be done there. An extension ledger can be added after go-live. This approach is not recommended approach, as reporting is very limited,his ledger.
  • C) No additional ledger. Some customers opt for not having any ledger at all for direct tax and only having a statistical tax depreciation area (to follow and report tax depreciation). This means you need to track pure direct tax related postings and reporting .

 

 

Figure 2: Ledger options with SAP S/4 HANA Private Cloud Edition.

There is available Corporate Income Tax Framework, however, the  country scope is limited and is not planned to be extended, so usually not very commonly discussed.

 

2.     Direct Tax in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition you can have statistical depreciation areas for tax and an extension ledger, but it is currently not possible to have full ledger for tax. This means options B and C from previous chapter are valid approaches.

  • B) Extension ledger. Having an extension ledger (on top of your local ledger (Ledger 2, in below example) enables you to make manual postings into the ledger, to have all direct tax adjustments in one ledger (reported together with the underlying ledger). An extension ledger supports only manual postings to balance sheet and P&L accounts. No postings to reconciliation accounts or other automated postings are supported. This means that no manual postings to subledgers, vendor, customer, asset or material can be done there.
    • An extension ledger can be added after go-live. This approach is not recommended approach, as reporting is very limited, read from this ledger.
  • C) No additional ledger. Some customers opt for not having any ledger at all for direct tax and only having a statistical tax depreciation area (to follow and report tax depreciation). This means you need to track pure direct tax related postings and reporting outside your SAP system. SAP pre-delivers per country depreciation areas, which typically includes also a tax depreciation area, but there are country specific differences.
    • Note! Currently only one customer specific (statistical) depreciation area(area 16)  can be added (for local GAAP), during initial implementation, not after go-live (scope item 5HG). So, if you need an additional depreciation area, it can only be added before go-live (no asset postings can exist when you add it). In some cases, you might also have requirements for an additional depreciation area for insurance follow-up (not direct tax). This means it is extra important to check you depreciation areas in the implementation phase. 

 

 

Figure 3: Ledger options in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition.

The Corporate Income Tax Framework , is also available, but also with limited country scope and is not planned to be extended, so usually not very commonly discussed.

 

3.     Profitability and Performance Management, taking automation to the next level

So far, we have discussed ledgers and asset accounting, but what about all the other posting differences, how to automate them? This is where SAP Profitability & Performance management (PaPM) comes into picture.

PaPM is a strong calculation engine, which designed to be maintained by business users and not require too much IT support. It has multiple use cases, one of which is corporate income tax. It brings automation, transparency, auditability and process overview to the direct income tax process.  PaPM enables also AI-assisted tax analysis and insights through integration with the Joule copilot.

Using the underlying data discussed in previous chapters, you can complete the remaining calculations and adjustments in PaPM. This enables to have a systematic and rule-based approach for temporary and permanent adjustment, as well as other adjustments. Optionally, PaPM can also make postings back to the (both for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition), for a single source of truth of direct tax postings. Technically PaPM can integrate to any source (also non-SAP), so you can also write back data to SAP ECC.

Figure 4: PaPM example with integration to Full tax ledger, together with PaPm and S/4 HANA Private Cloud edition.

To speed up a PaPM implementation you can use the SAP created sample content (SAP PaPM Sample Content All), for further information on the  SAP PaPM Tax Sample content, click here.  In addition to SAP sample content, there are multiple tax partners who create and maintain even more detailed sample content.

 

 

Figure 5: Overview of Corporate income tax with SAP.

 

It is worth noticing that PaPm comes with multiples other use cases also, BEPS pillar 2, Transfer pricing, Sustainability, Agile planning & Simulations, Activity based costing, etc.

 

 

Figure 6: Overview of PaPm use cases.

 

4.     Summary

This blog covered different options on how to handle direct tax, whether you only have partial support for direct tax in S/4HANA e.g. from statistical tax depreciation areas in asset accounting or having a full tax ledger, with PaPM you can gain further automation, auditability and process transparency. There are different options, depending on what type of setup suites your organization.  

 

Figure 7: Comparison Table: Direct Tax Management in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud, Public Cloud, and PaPM.

 

  • How automated is your direct tax processes, are you fully automated and auditable or are you using excel?

entry.title: Exploring Configuration and Security Analysis in SAP Cloud ALM ‚Äì IT Admin perspective
entry.content:
As an IT administrator, one of my constant concerns is security compliance. With multiple systems, services, and configurations to manage, it‚Äôs not always easy to answer simple questions like:

  • Are my systems compliant with SAP security recommendations?
  • What changed since yesterday?
  • Which configuration needs immediate attention?

This is where Configuration & Security Analysis (CSA) in SAP Cloud ALM became extremely useful in my daily operations. 

In this blog, I‚Äôd like to share my hands-on experience with CSA‚Äîhow I set it up, how I use it, and how the new Validation capabilities helped me move from monitoring to real-time compliance management.

Getting Started ‚Äì Setting Up CSA

To start with, I enabled data collection in CSA - Data Stores app.

For our on-premise ABAP systems, the setup was straightforward but required a few prerequisites. 

  • After ensuring  ST-A/PI and ST-PI were installed, I logged into the relevant client and executed /n/SDF/ALM_SETUP.  
  • In the Activate Use Cases step, I flagged Configuration & Security Analysis as active. From that point onward, the system started pushing configuration data to SAP Cloud ALM once per day. More information here.

Tip:  When something doesn‚Äôt work as expected, transaction SLG1 (Object: /SDF/CALM, Sub-object: CSA) quickly helped me identify data collection issues.  For example: please refer SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

For SAP Cloud services, the experience was even smoother‚Äîdata collection was already handled via SAP Managed Connectivity, and all I had to do was switch the data collection to ON in the CSA app. For more information, click here.

First Impression ‚Äì CSA Data Stores Application

Once data collection was active, I spent most of my time in the CSA Data Stores application analysing my configuration items. This quickly became my go-to place to understand what‚Äôs happening across my services and systems.

Store Browser ‚Äì Starting Point

The Store Browser gave me a consolidated view of configuration stores across all systems. I could drill down into individual configuration items , status of the event,  latest data collected date & time.

Changes ‚Äì Tracking Modifications Over Time

The Changes page shows what changed, when, and how‚Äîideal for audit reviews and root-cause analysis. This was particularly useful during audits, when I needed to explain: ‚ÄúWhat exactly changed, and when?‚Äù

Search ‚Äì Finding What Matters

While the Search page allows for quick searches across configuration keys and values. This is a lifesaver when investigating specific parameters across landscapes.

Administration ‚Äì Delivers an overview

The administration page provides data quality insights for each service and system, helping identify incomplete or outdated data collections.

The Missing Piece ‚Äì What Do I Do With This Data?

While CSA Data Stores gave me excellent visibility, I initially felt something was missing.

I could see the data,
I could monitor changes,
‚Ä¶but I still asked myself:

‚ÄúIs my system actually compliant?‚Äù

You can get the compliance status of the items through the store browser but it is quite a cumbersome process analysing each item key and value and the corresponding security recommendation. (Refer to Content)

That‚Äôs when SAP introduced the Configuration & Security Analysis ‚Äì Validation application‚Äîand that changed everything.

Validation ‚Äì Turning Data into Compliance Insights

The Validation app allows me to run compliance checks against SAP-recommended security rules. For the first time, I wasn‚Äôt just looking at raw configuration data‚ÄîI was seeing meaningful compliance results.

Validation Overview Page

The Validation Overview page provides:

  • A compliance score per system
  • Clear graphical and tabular views
  • A quick way to identify non-compliant systems

Since the results are always based on the latest data collection, I didn‚Äôt have to worry about outdated information.

The next level drill down displayed all the checks associated with the service/system.

I was glad I could get the necessary information of the relevant check like store ID, store name, and the configuration items in detailed view.

Let‚Äôs see how a check is evaluated and a service/system is rated complaint or non-complaint.

Understanding a Check ‚Äì A Real Example

Let‚Äôs take a pre-shipped ABAP check:

  • Check Name: login/no_automatic_user_sapstar = 1
  • Purpose: Prevents login with the hardcoded SAP* user after deletion‚Äîan essential security control.
  • How it Works:
    • Configuration key: NAME = login/no_automatic_user_sapstar
    • Value = 1 ‚Üí check is considered Compliant
    • Value = 0 ‚Üí check is considered Non-Compliant

This clarity makes compliance decisions easy and auditable.

When I saw a system flagged as non-compliant, I could immediately drill down to see the exact configuration value that caused it. This made follow-ups much more efficient.

Drilling Down ‚Äì From Overview to Root Cause

What I really liked about CSA is the navigation design:

  1. Landscape Level ‚Äì Overall compliance status
  2. System Level ‚Äì Check results per system
  3. Check Level ‚Äì Detailed explanation, configuration items, and runtime details

This step-by-step drill down felt intuitive and helped me quickly move from ‚Äúsomething is wrong‚Äù to ‚Äúthis is what needs to be fixed.‚Äù

Configuring Checks ‚Äì Staying in Control

As an administrator, I also appreciated the Configuration capabilities.

From the Validation Overview page, I found an option to Configure a Service/System based on my needs. All I had to do was to click on Configuration button.

From the Configuration page, I could enable or disable data collection per system

Details of each fields are described here.

Upon navigating to next level, I could

  • View the details of the checks
  • Activate or deactivate checks
  • Assign scope to checks 

Since the checks are pre-shipped by SAP, I couldn‚Äôt modify their logic‚Äîbut honestly, that gave me confidence that the rules were aligned with SAP best practices. Supported checks.

I tried my experience by logging to SAP‚Äôs demo tenant. User details for Configuration & Security Analysis can be found here.

Enhanced Visibility in Data Stores Cards

Another small but valuable improvement was seeing check compliance directly on the Data Stores card view. Even without opening Validation, I could immediately spot systems with poor compliance based on the card status.

This helped during quick health checks and having discussions.

What CSA Changed for Me

From a user perspective, CSA helped me move from:

  1. Centralised visibility
  2. Automated compliance checks
  3. Proactive security monitoring

Conclusion

Using Configuration & Security Analysis in SAP Cloud ALM has significantly improved how I manage security and compliance across my landscape. With the addition of the Validation app, CSA is no longer just about monitoring‚Äîit‚Äôs about actionable compliance insights.

Over to You

How has your experience been with Configuration & Security Analysis in SAP Cloud ALM?
Are there specific checks or scenarios where CSA helped you the most?

Feel free to share your thoughts or questions in the comments‚Äîhappy to exchange experiences with the community!

entry.title: Re: Direct link to LMS custom pages
entry.content:
Dear @mbshatto 

Currently, there is no way to generate the direct link to a custom page using the generate link tool. It was never a part of initial scope of the tool's design. However, based on customer feedback, it can be considered as a potential enhancement for future updates.

  • At present, the standard way to access the new custom pages is via the dropdown (which is kinda concealed) and hence making a custom card or banner as an entry point for custom pages is more of a workaround to make them more visible and discoverable on the LHP. 
  • "Links" anyway (even in the legacy) were maintained by customers as they can change and hence break the navigation. Not just the copied URLs to the custom pages but many links for that matter that customers put in those cards. We have Link type custom cards (supporting URL's) that can also be dynamic and the onus of maintaining and updating those links afresh is on the admin managing those custom cards or banners."

At this point, in case this is desired to have a custom page link, it's necessary to navigate the to custom page and copy it from the browser Address Bar. Still, this link may stop working later on as this is not the ideal way to navigate to a custom page. For further details, please refer to the KBA - 3544350 - Unable to Generate Direct Link to Custom Page in SAP SuccessFactors Learning - SAP for Me.

Thank you,

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Connecting to S/4HANA Private Cloud OData with OAuth (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
Introduction

Modern integration scenarios increasingly rely on secure, token-based connectivity. In SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration, the OData receiver adapters (V2 and V4) support a range of authentication mechanisms‚Äîsuch as Basic Authentication, Client Certificate, and OAuth 2.0. Out of the box, OAuth-based connectivity is common for public cloud services, where provider endpoints and identity flows are standardized and well-documented.

But what if your OData endpoint sits in a private cloud or behind corporate network boundaries, and it‚Äôs protected by OAuth 2.0? This introduction sets the scene for a practical, step-by-step walkthrough that shows how to connect SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration to private cloud OData services using OAuth 2.0 with the client credentials grant type. You‚Äôll learn how to enable OAuth for OData services, define the OAuth client in SAP S/4HANA, and wire everything up in SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration so your flows can obtain and use access tokens seamlessly.

 

Prepare the SAP S/4HANA

Enable OAuth authentication for Odata services

V2

  • Access transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE for OData service administration
  • Locate your target OData V2 service in the Service Catalog view
  • Verify the service is properly activated and running
  • Click the OAuth button from the available menu option
  • Select a package to store the to be created OAuth scope
  • Check the status for successful activation
  • All created objects are available via the assigned package (SE80)

V4

  • Access transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN for OData service administration
  • Locate your target OData V4 service in the Service Groups view
  • Verify the service is properly activated and running
  • Click the OAuth button from the available menu option
  • Enable Oauth
  • Validate activation status and scope

Create integration user

Perform this step only if no technical integration user exists or if the scenario requires a dedicated user. If a suitable user is already available, reuse it and adjust its authorizations as needed.

  • Navigate to SAP transaction SU01
  • Enter a user name and select the create user button 
  • Define a last name for the user in the address section
  • Navigate to the ‚ÄúLogon Data‚Äù section
  • Set the user type to ‚ÄúSystem", define a password and save the changes

Create an OAuth client

Proceed with this step only if an OAuth client has not yet been created for the designated system user. If a client already exists, reuse it and update its configuration details as needed.

  • Navigate to SAP transaction /nSOAUTH2
  • Select ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù and then select ‚ÄúCreate..."
  • Set the Client Type to ‚ÄúConfidential‚Äù or ‚ÄúPublic‚Äù based upon the general IT security governance rules, define the OAuth 2.0 Client ID. Keep in mind that this has to be equivalent to the previously created or existing user. Provide a description and set the token lifetime according to the internal governance rules. Select ‚ÄúNext"
  • The goal for this client is to authenticate itself using client id and secret therefore deselect option ‚ÄúSSL Client Certificate‚Äù then select ‚ÄúNext"
  • Deselect ‚ÄúGrant Type SAML 2.0 Bearer Active‚Äù and select ‚ÄúGrant Type Client Credentials Active‚Äù hence the goal is to activate the client for grant type client credentials. Select ‚ÄúNext‚Äù.
  • Add the OAuth 2.0 Scope ID of the OData service to be called and select ‚ÄúNext‚Äù
  • Finally review the settings and select ‚ÄúFinish‚Äù. The result should look like this.

Create authorization role

This step is only necessary if either no role exists or if it‚Äôs required to have a dedicated role per integration. If there is an existing role you should use it and in case necessary adjust its details.  
 
The instructions focus on the integration aspects. Therefore role definitions and the assignments of service related authorisations are not covered. To fine-grain authorisations for OAuth clients to scopes use of authorisation object S_SCOPE.

Configure SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration

In SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration, the configuration provided with this blog includes a downloadable iFlow that mirrors the setup described below and can be used as a reference template, then adapted to your needs. The iFlow consists of one main flow and two local subprocesses.

For demonstration purposes, the main flow is triggered by a timer and first checks whether a valid access token is already available. If a token exists, the main flow delegates processing to the subprocess responsible for invoking the target OData service. If no token is found, the flow requests a new OAuth token and, once obtained, proceeds to call the OData service via the same subprocess. This structure isolates token handling from service invocation, making the solution easier to reuse, maintain, and extend for different scenarios.

To optimize performance and reduce load on the S/4HANA backend, the access token is cached in a local variable within the iFlow, avoiding unnecessary token requests on each run. In the rare event the backend invalidates or terminates the token, the iFlow supports an on-demand refresh via a dedicated header parameter. While a production-ready setup could automate this with an exception subprocess that detects token-related errors and triggers a controlled refresh, note that‚Äîfor demo purposes‚Äîforced token refresh as part of error handling is not covered in this blog. Alternatively, you can manually re-trigger the interface using the same header parameter to force a token refresh when needed.

Finally, the iFlow issues a request to the target OData service. To fully leverage the OData receiver adapter‚Äôs capabilities, ensure you upload the service‚Äôs EDMX metadata file. With the EDMX in place, the adapter can discover and configure resources (entity sets, operations) correctly and orchestrate backend calls automatically. Without it, resources cannot be resolved properly, you are forced to maintain endpoints and authorization details manually, and the adapter cannot automatically invoke the backend service as intended.

IFlow template

The iFlow template can be downloaded from the following GitHub repository.

entry.title: Re: How to export Customer credit segment data?
entry.content:
Dear @MSSAP07,

Option 1: Display Credit Account Data (F4825) and export to spreadsheet

Use the list/reporting app that is meant to display credit master data and then export.

  1. Open Display Credit Account Data (F4825)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/083777d1580a41da91e7935d1787b155.html

  1. Filter for your population and Go
  2. In the results table:
    • Use Settings Columns or Adapt Filters/Columns, depending on your UI
    • Add columns for:
      • Credit Segment
      • Credit Limit + Currency
      • Risk Class
      • Credit Check Rule
  3. Use Export Spreadsheet

Option 2: Use the standard Credit Management Master Data API (OData)

SAP provides a dedicated API for credit management master data Credit Management Master Data (API_CRDTMBUSINESSPARTNER)

More details below:

https://api.sap.com/api/API_CRDTMBUSINESSPARTNER/resource/Credit_Account_Collaterals

To use it in Public Cloud you set up a Communication Arrangement for communication scenario SAP_COM_0740 that‚Äôs the scenario tied to this API

SAP Notes below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3436543

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3575895

This is the most reliable option if you need repeatable extraction for audits/validation

Option 3: Custom CDS / Custom Analytical Query extract

If you don‚Äôt have the API/scenario available build an extract using released CDS and expose/export it:

  • SAP delivers credit reporting CDS such as I_CreditAccountExtended commonly used for credit reporting

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3315841

  • You can create a Custom CDS View / Custom Analytical Query on released views and then export results or even expose as an external API if needed

Summary:

In Public Cloud the credit segment fields you listed are not part of BP master data export they belong to SAP Credit Management. That‚Äôs why Export Master Data Business Partners won‚Äôt give you Credit Segment / Credit Limit / Risk Class / Rules

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Cutting Through the Complexity: Lease Accounting in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Lease accounting under IFRS 16 and ASC 842 continues to challenge finance and project teams alike. The calculations themselves are straightforward ‚Äî it‚Äôs the classification and operational handling that create complexity.

In SAP Cloud ERP, the Contract and Lease Management (CLM) functionality simplifies this challenge by delivering a standardized, automated approach for both lessee and lessor accounting.

This blog explains how the system supports different lease types ‚Äî and what that means in practical terms for finance teams adopting a clean-core cloud solution.

Lessee Accounting ‚Äì For Companies Using Assets

If your business leases assets such as office space, vehicles, or equipment, you‚Äôre acting as a lessee. The system handles these scenarios through Scope Item 1T6: Lease-In Accounting.

When you activate a lease contract, S/4HANA Cloud automatically:

  • Calculates the Right-of-Use (ROU) asset and lease liability based on future payments.
  • Posts interest expense on the liability and depreciation on the asset each period.
  • Integrates everything into the Universal Journal for full auditability.

From a finance perspective, this means that once the contract data is entered correctly, the system takes care of recognition and periodic postings ‚Äî freeing you from manual calculations or offline models.

IFRS 16 vs ASC 842: Two Frameworks, One Process

  • IFRS 16 treats nearly all leases as finance leases ‚Äî meaning they appear on the balance sheet.
  • ASC 842, used in the US, distinguishes between:
    • Finance leases, where interest and depreciation are shown separately.
    • Operating leases, where the expense appears as a single straight-line amount in the income statement, even though both the asset and liability exist in the background.

Both standards are supported natively. This allows multinational organizations to run a single process while reporting correctly under different frameworks.

Short-Term and Low-Value Exemptions

S/4HANA Cloud also supports the practical exemptions under IFRS 16 ‚Äî for leases under 12 months or of low-value assets. These are recorded but not capitalized, keeping disclosure complete without overstating the balance sheet.

Explore more: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Contract & Lease Management ‚Äì Simplify and Lower the Cost of Compliance

Lessor Accounting ‚Äì For Companies Providing Assets

Some organizations lease out their own equipment, vehicles, or real estate. In these cases, you‚Äôre the lessor.

The Public Edition supports standard lessor models under both IFRS 16 and ASC 842, helping finance teams recognize income correctly depending on the nature of the lease.

Finance Lease (IFRS 16)

If the lessee effectively takes on most of the risks and rewards of ownership:

  • The asset is replaced by a lease receivable.
  • Income is recognized as interest over the lease term.

Sales-Type Lease (ASC 842)

Used when the lease is effectively a sale at commencement:

  • Revenue and cost of goods sold are recognized immediately.
  • Interest income is then recognized over time.

Direct Financing Lease (ASC 842)

Applied when there is no upfront selling profit:

  • A lease receivable is created.
  • Income arises gradually through interest over the lease period.

In practice, most organizations using CLM in the Public Edition are handling a limited number of such lessor contracts ‚Äî for example, internal leasing of IT assets or vehicles between entities ‚Äî rather than running a large-scale commercial leasing operation.

Learn more: Enabling a Renting Business Model with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Subscription Billing

Making the Right Call on Lease Type

The most common challenge project teams face is not the posting itself ‚Äî it‚Äôs the classification decision at the start.
The following simple logic can help you decide which path applies:

  1. Are you the user or provider of the asset?
    ‚Üí User ‚Üí Lessee Accounting (Scope Item 1T6)
    ‚Üí Provider ‚Üí Lessor Accounting
  2. Which reporting standard applies?
    • If yes ‚Üí Finance or Sales-Type Lease.
    • If no ‚Üí Operating or Direct Financing Lease.
    • IFRS 16 ‚Üí All leases (except short-term/low-value) are Finance Leases.
    • ASC 842 ‚Üí Determine whether the lease transfers ownership or risk.
  3. Enter the contract in CLM using the relevant Fiori app ‚Äî the system will handle valuation and posting automatically.

Key Takeaways

  • Lessee accounting (Scope Item 1T6) is the core capability in Cloud ERP.
  • The system supports both IFRS 16 and ASC 842 with standard content.
  • Lessor models (Finance, Sales-Type, Direct Financing) are available for entities providing assets.
  • The clean-core approach minimizes maintenance and simplifies audit readiness.

Learn More

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Contract and Lease Management (Public Edition)
  • SAP Community Topic: Finance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Learning Hub ‚Äì Lease Accounting Fundamentals
  • SAP Best Practices Explorer ‚Äì Scope Item 1T6

entry.title: Re: Why using the dynamic variant of CALL TRANSFORMATION if the static one can be used?
entry.content:
Another explanation is that maybe the developers have the feeling of being good developers if they use something complex.

I guess that a good developer would:

  1. Respect the development guidelines (and advocate to improve them).
  2. Choose the appropriate technology (e.g. to produce XML, use an XML Transformation language instead of pure ABAP, or eventually XML API).
  3. Code the simplest way.

In the code here, there's no reason to over-complexify the code.

The simplest way is definitely:

       CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE data = gt_ot
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Traveling with My little Puppy and Finding Balance Beyond Tech :)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Marla. I work as a Senior Data and AI Developer, and Today, I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobby as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series. ü§ó Outside of work, one hobby has become very important to me over the last few years: traveling and exploring the world with my little puppy Carlo üòÉ üê∂

It might sound simple, but it requires a lot of planning and creativity. How I organize my trips has also influenced how I think about systems and processes. Carlo is not just my travel companion. He is part of the journey and the reason many of these experiences exist in the first place.

How and when did I start this hobby?

I did not plan for this to become a hobby. It started naturally when I got Carlo five years ago and realized I did not want to stop traveling or leave him alone while I‚Äôm on vacation ü•π. So naturally, instead of adapting my life to travel, I adapted travel to my life.üòâ

Short trips, nature-focused destinations, dog-friendly cities and countries  ( I can totally recommend Croatia and Italy ), and flexible planning became the default. Over time, this turned into a routine and something I actively look forward to. Together, Carlo, my partner Niklas, and I have discovered many new places, from quiet nature spots to vibrant cities, always at a pace that works for all of us.

 

 

Me and Carlo on the way to attend a workshop in Belgrade- Serbia

 

visiting the stunning Externsteine in the Teutoburg Forest - Germany

 Having the best time in The Hague - the Netherlands

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest value is presence. Traveling with a dog forces you to slow down. You walk more, you observe more, and you plan less around attractions and more around experiences. It clears my head in a way that very few things do, especially after intense project phases or long weeks in front of screens. It is also grounding. No notifications matter when you are on a forest path with a leash in your hand, or when Carlo decides that a certain spot is worth stopping for.

Challenges and how I deal with them

Traveling with a dog is not always easy. Not every hotel is dog-friendly. Public transport rules vary(For example, in Austria, Carlo has to wear a muzzle when using public transportation üòÖ ). Planning takes more effort, especially across countries. I learned to research carefully, build buffers, and always have a backup plan.

A proud moment

My proudest moments are not big milestones. They are small wins. The first long train trip went smoothly. The first international trip without stress. Finding places where Carlo is relaxed, welcome, and curious rather than overwhelmed.

Those moments tell me that good preparation pays off.

Celebrating a friend's birthday in Zaragoza - Spain

 

 

 

Traviling to Berlin for TechEd 2025

 

 

flying to Mallorca -Spain

 

enjoying a ride in Texel- the Netherlands

Tools and resources for beginners

For anyone starting out, these are essential:

Dog-friendly accommodation platforms and search filters
Basic travel gear such as a good leash, a portable water bowl, and a transport-safe harness
Patience and realistic expectations. You do not need expensive equipment. You need planning and awareness.

 

Chilling at the Hotel in k√ºlingsborn-Germany

 

 

Flying to Spain again üòÑ

 

 

 

Road trips with the car

 

Tips for getting started

Start small.üòâ Begin with day trips, then weekends, then longer journeys. Observe how your dog reacts and adjust. Do not aim for perfection. Aim for learning. The same applies to learning new SAP technologies. Iteration beats overplanning.

How I keep improving

I learn by doing. Each trip teaches me something new. Traveling with Carlo constantly challenges me to be more flexible and attentive. I also exchange tips with other dog owners and travelers. Reflection after each journey helps me improve the next one. Continuous improvement does not need formal training. It needs attention.

Common misconceptions

A common myth is that traveling with a dog is restrictive.In reality, it changes priorities, but it also opens new perspectives. You discover quieter places, nature-focused destinations, and a slower pace that many people are actually looking for.

Visiting Heidelberg

 

 

Carlo in Berlin üòÑ

 

 

Chilling in Mallorca

Where to learn more

There are many blogs and communities focused on dog-friendly travel, especially in Europe and North America. Local communities are often more helpful than large platforms.

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it seems.

Traveling with a dog is about systems thinking. You balance constraints, dependencies, timing, and user experience, where the user just happens to have four legs.

In SAP projects, especially in data and AI, we design architectures that must be robust, flexible, and humane. This hobby constantly reminds me that good systems serve real needs, not just technical elegance.It also helps me show up better at work. More focused, more patient, and more grounded.

What is next?

After discovering so many places together, our next big plan is to cross the Atlantic. Carlo and I are preparing for a longer journey, with New York and Toronto at the top of the list. It will be a new level of planning, learning, and adapting, and I am already looking forward to what we will discover next.

Thanks for reading. If you travel with your dog, or if you have found a hobby that helps you disconnect and think better, I would love to hear about it.

 

Hello from Karlsruhe

Coming up  next ü•Å

I am happy to pass the baton to  @HakanHasalman, who will introduce his writing hobby. ü§ó

 

With Love,
Marla & Carlo

entry.title: Re: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach
entry.content:
Hi @Gaurish-Dessai Thank you, this is a valid suggestion. We had discussed thsi with our team while we were implementing the Discovery-first approach and here are the few discussion points that came up, based on implementation approach, leading to the current approach.

We found few challenges.

1. In many cases the business user is not aware what they 'want' in AI. For many the SAP solution simply works well for them. Thus this discovery-first process tries to stay consciously away from telling a business user what they need. The 6 steps is an approach to onboard Business Users to the journey and appreciating the value.

2. Taking an entry from ticket analysis, we find people tend to fall into the trap of 'how will I implement it' and the investigation goes away to automation than stay with AI. While Automations bring value for IT by addressing Runners and Repeaters in process and problems, AI addresses value stream. 

3. AI in its current form acts more as a 'helper' and thus we still need 'man-in-between', and not truly autonomous. But with the speed of maturity and training, we have seen R-A-G models where accuracy is sometime better than humans in first pass. This needs not only an AI solution but also change the way AI led automations work.

4. Agree, the idea is to get few POCs (3-5 high value cases we are targeting) done successfully which bring high value, and create the business case for further investment/adaptation. Thus, the Discovery-first approach creates a backlog.

Would like to pursue formalizing the approach. We can further debate on it. Do DM me and we could collaborate in defining the right approach.

 

Best regards

Trijoy Saikia

https://www.linkedin.com/in/trijoysaikia/

entry.title: Re: Bulgaria EUR Transition_Material inventory balance Mi...
entry.content: Hi @AdyashaPatra, sorry for my delayed response, I somehow missed your followup question. You can use multiple approaches when it comes to choosing from the available movement types. If you use movement type 301, a revaluation posting will be posted on the individual goods movement level if the material valuation differs in the sending and receiving plant. If you use 501/502 or 561/562 to independently remove the inventory from the old plant and the goods receipt in the new plant, you can avoid any side effects from direct conversion from BGN to EUR in the goods movement. You have to decide which approach works best for you.

entry.title: Re: End-to-End Message Tracking and Retry Control in SAP Cloud integration
entry.content:
Hi Sushant,

Great explanation.

For Dead Letter Queue processing, I highly recommend using DataStore as your storage and reprocessing medium.

Here are few arguments in favor of DataStore:

First - you can save pretty much anything you want to a DS entry ID. You can even merge multiple attributes into single entry ID if that helps. This makes searching in DataStore monitor super easy. No need to hunt down Message IDs - which is your only filtering option in JMS queue monitor.

Second - you can set up automatic job for reprocessing from DataStore with lower frequency, plus you have the option to run it on demand with custom selection criteria. Want to reprocess all business object IDs (like Sales orders) or Message IDs from Proxy messages? Easy. With JMS, you're stuck with manual handling in the UI.
Sure, you can create a reprocessing iFlow for DLQ JMS as well, but you can't configure retries to run every x hours (limited to start with max 60min -> after exponential max 3h)

Third - JMS queues are really limited (30 by default, max 100), so if you create one DLQ for every JMS sender queue, you're quickly doubling your queue count and running out of resources. You could work around this with some generic-use DLQ queues, but then you need to correlate the generic JMS with specific JMS counterparts using JMS headers. Maybe group several interfaces together and maintain grouped JMS queues instead, but then you do not know what messages belongs to what interfaces... With DataStore - you can create any number of them. Easy maintanance.

Speaking of overcoming JMS limits and adding generalization, unification, and reusability to your landscape - I suggest everyone check out the Pipeline Concept. Even if you don't use it fully, at least look at the design decisions and apply them to your custom templates. For example, there's a really advanced DataStore retry mechanism described here:
https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/process-integration-pipeline-extension-restart-via-data-store/ba-p/14153116 
just discover -> copy -> configure -> deploy.
Works like a charm in my integrations !

All these tips are especially valuable when you're dealing with high-volume processing - manual manipulation in the JMS UI becomes a total nightmare in those scenarios üòû

OK... some might argue that JMS is more performant than DataStore when it comes to high-volume processing. I totally agree, which is why initial buffering always happens on JMS queues - only the DLQ utilizes DataStore. So far I haven't run into any issues with DB locking or releasing.
Second counterargument - DataStores eat into that 32GB tenant limit. Fair point, but again - DataStore is only for reprocessing purposes. If you manage it wisely, this shouldn't be an issue either.

 

br

Mateusz

entry.title: Can the result of CALL TRANSFORMATION be empty?
entry.content:
I'm surprised by this code:

    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE data = itab
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |Error : XML generation is impossible| ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_xslt_runtime_error INTO DATA(lo_ex).
        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |Error : Incompatibility between SAP format and expected |
                                      && |format { lo_ex->s2 }| ).
          gv_error = abap_true.
        ENDIF.
      CATCH cx_transformation_error INTO DATA(lo_error).
        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |ERROR : Incompatibility between SAP format and expected |
                                      && |format { lo_error->get_text( ) }| ).
          gv_error = abap_true.
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

My questions:

  1. Lines 6 to 8: is it possible that without error the XML is empty?
  2. Lines 11 and 16: isn't the generated XML always empty if there's an error, why testing if it's empty?
  3. Line 12: why considering that the attribute S2 is filled in all cases when the exception CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is raised, and why not using LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) instead?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - API Availability for BP Extens...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

I apologize but I didn't see your comment earlier. Below are the answers to your questions

Question 1

In this API the item key is AccountingDocument + CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocumentItemID
So:

  • YES Accounting Journal Entry / FI Accounting Document number is CORRECT

  • IF Customer Invoice Document Number is only correct if it is the same FI Accounting Document number produced by the posting often yes in FI-based invoicing runs but not the SD Billing Document number

  • NO AR Open Item Document Number isn‚Äôt a separate key here the open item is a line item in the accounting document

Question 2

In Public Cloud the item number is specified as 3 numeric characters for example 001 BUT it‚Äôs mixing between documentation and system. Correct key you will find in Manage Journal Entries app below:

 

 

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/8247ba7cf3344cb6b1092443d10cdebf.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/de7030b74705456997aa9b9b51e66427.html

Question 3

Yes the standard Change pattern in this API is:

  • Put the new value in the ‚Ä¶Change node and

  • Set FieldValueChangeIsRequested to true so SAP actually applies the change

To clear the payment block, you send an initial/blank value for PaymentBlockingReasonCode and FieldValueChangeIsRequested=true

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content: In the row level trigger, the trigger will not fire for a no-op statement. But a statement level trigger will always fire. The delete is still a no-op since no rows are impacted so there isn't a row for old values. What would the values of OLD be for a non-existent row? There aren't any values so the result set old_rec would have no rows. .
